Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game is a cross between Dance Dance Revolution / Stepmania and Puzzle Quest.If you reacted to that sentence with "hey that sounds cool," this game is for you. Not certain? Still worth a look.Playable with the keyboard, a gamepad, or a dance pad (which I really want to try one of these days), the basic gist of the gameplay is hitting arrows in time with a beat a la DDR. For the Puzzle Quest influence, this has an RPG story where you beat monsters to collect items and proceed up a tower. You flip between three "boards": one board's arrows are attacks aimed at you, and clearing the arrow defends against the attack; one board will regenerate your mana; a third board is active when you cast a spell, and nailing that sequence means your spell succeeds.The dialogue is refreshingly snarky, and fully voice-acted.The all-important question: how's the music? Very good, and there's a solid variety too. At least, variety within the style - they're all going to be a bit dancy-technoey.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												Though it's easy to go "oh it's just DDR/Stepmania/etc" there really aren't any games that play like Sequence does, forcing you to manage multiple stepcharts, resources, and commands on top of the basic 'hit the notes when they hit the bottom of the screen' gameplay we're all familiar with.  Which probably sounds daunting but the game's tailored to all varieties of skill levels.  And then you add in a pretty solid soundtrack and genuinely enjoyable writing and art and you've got a very solid package.That said, be ready to (ugh) grind.  There's a heavy RNG factor that can force you to repeat content or spontaneously penalize you, and that really does drag down the game.  I mean the core game is fun, but, y'know, somewhere around the tenth fight against a monster for the material you only needed 3 of you start getting kinda worn out.But that's basically the one strike against an otherwise brilliant game.

Posted: January 5, 2012
												With a great story, beautiful graphics, and a rhythm based fight mechanic, this game gives a great musical twist on a classic genre. What a great game, the problem is that there just isn't enough of it. I hope Iridium Studios keeps making games, this is a great start.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												This game is excellent. Normally, RPGs and music games both face issues, but I can't readily see them in this title. It took the gameplay of Rockband: Unplugged for the PSP and made it actually functional, and into an intuitive battle system. The RPG elements, with the ability to gain and lose levels as you spend time bettering your character, made character building interesting and every upgrade felt impactful. The voice acting was well done too, though similarly with There Came an Echo the character development was not endearing, focused too much on antagonistic dialouge rather than meaningful trait building. Still, however, you can skip these scenes so you can get away from that as much as possible. The game itself, I'll warn, has little replay value. There's no software to add custom tracks like in Audiosurf, the music gets used on multiple levels and, given you are grinding, you get to hear the songs over and over again. If the music was bad, this would have been worse of an issue but I can't honestly say that the songs were terrible and didn't go so far as to play abrasive music from Dubstep, etc. Other things I'd change would be additions of things like local PvP, clearer labeling on the spell circle to tell which spell was which and what numbers corresponded to which slice of the circle, and more than seven levels/three battle senarios per level.  All in all it is a fun game. For 5$, it has about as much content as you'd expect and with as polished as it looks, sounds, and feels I can't recommend it enough.

Posted: February 6, 2015
												As a long-time rhythm game (in this case Stepmania) player, I was really excited for Sequence. The game looked to be just the right mix between rhythm and RPG elements, with a fun soundtrack to back it up. Unfortunately the game gets a little too grindy for my taste - you can beat pretty much any encounter in the game provided that you're a high enough level. Leveling up is a chore though, and the bonus for beating an enemy skillfully isn't enough to outweigh the immense grind. A lot of the depth of the game involved simple grinding to get better levels, as later bosses had too much health and an item or a couple of levels was enough to make it easy. The grinding is really boring though as the regular creatures usually don't pose much threat. If you're a fan of rhythm games I'd recommend picking it up, but if you're new maybe give it a pass or play it on a lower difficulty. I played it on Hard because it said "for the not musically challenged," but most of the difficulty came from luck not going in my favor.

												I was skeptical about this game at first, but after two near-sleepless nights I can honestly say I'm super addicted. Posted: March 2, 2015
												Games like Sequence are the reason Kickstarter and the Indie Game movement exist. It's not a perfect game, not everyone is going to enjoy it and it will never receive a lot of fame and recognition. However, for the niche audience that can appreciate it, Sequence is a game like no other.The closest thing I can relate Sequence to is Puzzle Quest. The game doesn't play like Puzzle Quest but what that game did for Match-3 games, Sequence does for the rhythm genre. The base game has you traveling up a tower by fighting enemies, collecting their dropped items, and synthesising items such as keys, weapons and armor. Battles give you experience which will level up your stats while armor and weapons are equipable and can also improve your abilities. Where Sequence differs from the average dungeon crawler is that combat is played out by putting you in a rhythm system similar to StepMania, if you're using a keyboard, but with three separate boards. One board is defensive, one board is for building mana and one is for casting spells. On the first board, any notes that you miss will count as damage against you so catching them defends your HP. The second board will have a constant stream of notes. Missing them doesn't hurt you but catching them restores your mana which you need to cast spells. The last board stays dormant until you cast spells, the only way to damage your opponents. When you cast a spell, it takes mana and makes you complete a short rhythm sequence. Failing it causes the spell to fail but completing it will cast that spell. While it can be a lot to juggle at once, the game does a great job of teaching you and ramping up the difficulty slowly in order to build your skills both in game and out.The gameplay by itself is fun for a while but as the entire game is built around grinding items and EXP, it would get boring very quickly if it weren't for the well written story pushing players forward. The tone reminded me of The World Ends With You in the best possible way, but felt wholy unique. Your main character finds himself waking up in a tower with no idea how he got there. The voice of a girl named Naia tells you that you are stuck in this tower/game and you will need to make your way up 7 floors to escape so off you go. While there are some predictable moments, the story as a whole never becomes too transparent and despite a few moments when I swore I was done after one more battle, curiosity kept me pushing ever forward. The characters are all voiced as well and while none are particularly mind-blowing, it's a nice touch and the quality stayed consistent throughout. If you do find your bar set particularly high in regards to VO quality, they do have an option to turn it off as well although I doubt this will be necessary for most people.That's not to say the game isn't without it's rough spots. For a music-based game, Sequence has a surprisingly limited soundtrack of only about 10 songs that show up in battle. This means several monsters will have you playing the same songs repeatedly. Thankfully, they aren't bad and some of them I didn't mind repeating but considering each monster all but requires multiple playthroughs anyway, don't be surprised if you wind up hearing the same song 10+ times. As that suggests too, the gameplay is simply too grindy and while item drops are pretty common, it can be irritating when you need one specific item and have to fight the same monster over and over just to move forward. Finally, the song balance is a bit odd as by the end of the game, the length of the song decided more battles for me than my HP did. It felt like very artificial difficulty (you lose if the song ends before killing the enemy) and it would have been nicer to have some of the songs be just a bit longer, especially in Floor 7. Depending on your strategy, you may not have a problem with this but it showed up several times in my game.Overall, if you're looking for something different and enjoy music gameplay, Sequence is worth a shot.

Posted: March 1, 2015
												Taking a simple DDR based rthym game and turning into an RPG combat system was a suprisingly good idea. Unfortunately the way progression in the game is very grindy, but the core combat mechanics are more than fun enough to keep you playing. And while a simple arcade concept such as this could have easily gone with a cheesy and overly simplistic story, they went all out here, the game's got a very good story and is well voice acted.Simply put, for the cheap price it's currently available at (or even better, free with There came an echoe) it'll provide hours of fun and a great story. Can't recommend it enough, Iridium studios are quickly becoming a studio to watch out for.

Posted: December 8, 2014
												When I heard about this indie title, being addicted to rhythm games like Stepmania and the possibility to play with a dancepad already got me interested. Ready to press arrows blindly according to the patterns, what I really found is that Sequence is a simple rpg game, in which are injected rhythmic mechanics with average difficulty. Mixed genres dude!Iridium Studios managed to produce something difficult to classify, yet the gameplay alone will entertain you for a decent amount of time. Yes, because while I enjoyed the game in its essence - the crafting system, the bosses and the good ol' leveling up - the story and the characters can't really get you hooked.Plus, I don't get why sentences by the main character are constantly being interrupted: you feel like a spoiled brat who needs a lesson for no particular reason, and the moment after we're oh so important like the future of the world depends on us. XDPlot twists, kinda forced, kinda rushed. Someone likes that, others don't.Despite the full controller support, I fully played it on keyboard - more fit in handling the controls in my opinion - and it was a good experience overall: my playtime reached ~20 hours, not bad for an indie game so I cannot say I didn't enjoy the run! The achievements offer a medium challenge to accomplish, so if you're an achievement hunter this is a nice game to 100% .Finally, would you look at the price! Looks like an on-sale game already, so definitely give this title a chance if you're searching for something outside the box.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												Bit of a mixed bag, Sequence is a rhythm game about using three different playing to fight monsters.  There's the defense field in which you defend against incoming attacks by aggressors by blocking their attacks pressing the corresponding keys.  The spell field in which you cast spells with different effects such as DoT, healing, or fast recharge low damage spells.  And the mana field in which you replenish mana, which is used to cast spells, you can only have one of these fields open at a time and there is a time limit for defeating the monster, which is an interesting concept.  The monsters have a chance of dropping various items, the lower the more rare and they all give a different amount of experience. You use your experience to craft items, spell scrolls, or keys which you use to use to progress, herein lies some of the problems of the game.  It feels like a grind, just a huge grind.  You end up wasting so much time either killing the same monster over and over again to find that ONE item you need to make better gear or spells, and you can end up wasting all of that precious expereince you earned making you down on experience, although you do lose out on some items.  It just gets very very repetitive around floor four you notice none of the spells bring anything new to the table.  It doesn't help the writing isn't super compelling.  Not to mention the music is reused and the only time you feel like you're actually playing a rhythm game is when you're in the mana field, which is when the keys actually feel like they correspond to the music.  It's got cute ideas but it's riddled with flaws, it's worth checking out if you feel confident sinking money into just to get a feel for it, hey if you're into the grind and slamming on keys for 10 seconds at a time (roughly how long it takes to get your mana replensihed) then be my guest.

Posted: October 25, 2011
												Awesome indie game. It's a mix of RPG with stepmania/DDR/ITG. If you're good at any of these rhythm games, don't let the screenshots and videos fool you into thinking this is too easy. The challenge in this game comes from having to multi task all 3 different aspects of battle (gathering mana, defending, casting spells) and your ability to balance and decide which one to focus on. Its mechanics are also fairly simple and easy to get into.EDIT:  I just found out this game was patched to fix a bug where the hardest difficulty would randomly get changed to the easiest mode.  Now that I'm actually playing on the hardest difficulty, the charts are kinda hard by themselves but the battles are outright brutal now.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												A fantastic game in which all of the mechanics have been honed to perfection. The DDR Max-RPG hybrid system works flawlessly, the voice acting is top notch, and the dialogue is great. Little touches such as being able to spend experience points to increase synthesis success, having a practice mode to work on your timing, and more are all done well. The hand painted enviornments look gorgeous, and the character and enemy designs are great, although a couple of the later enemies are palette swaps of the early ones. The soundtrack is great, with several catchy songs you'll find yourself humming in the shower later. Unfortunately, the number of tracks is rather limited, and each enemy is assigned only one song, but the songs are still good enough that they don't get annoying. The only flaw I can find is that there is no free play mode, as at this point I have reached such a high level that even the hardest battles only take around thirty seconds to win. Still, its hard to fault a game for not letting you replay it enough, so I'll conclude by saying that this is the single best indie title I have had the pleasure of playing on Steam. A fantastic game that should be enjoyed by all.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Sequence is a rhythm RPG, which is, in and of itself, an interesting concept. It delivers this with surprisingly unique gameplay, an interesting story, and an excellent, albeit limited, selection of music to play along to.In terms of gameplay, it's not unlike DDR in that you have four arrows that you have to hit to the rhythm as they reach the bottom of the screen while music plays in the background. However, the similarities stop there. Combat involves rotating between three screens: your damage screen, your mana screen, and your spell screen. The damage screen represents incoming attacks from your opponent, and each arrow missed on this screen will result in your health taking a hit. The spell screen is used for all of the abilities in the game, where you must select what type of spell you want to perform and then hit every arrow in that spell for it to succeed. The mana screen grants mana, for casting spells, with every arrow that is hit. As a result, the game turns into a very interesting experience where you have to time spells so that you don't take too much damage, and prioritize each of these screens so that you can keep yourself alive and deplete your enemy's health bar before the song ends.When a battle concludes, loot is dropped. This loot can be used to craft specific items on each floor, such as new weapons and equipment, a key to get to the next level, and a few other secrets that are best observed within the game. Especially towards the end, there are some very interesting items that can be crafted, and a lot of secrets and hidden content. I highly recommend crafting every item in the game, waiting until after the credits, and then exploring a bit more based on what you learn. This game quickly becomes intriguing, and knows how to deliver on it.One point of criticism I have for this game is that, if you're looking to craft all of the items in the game, it can get a little repetitive. Each enemy has the same song every time you fight them, and when you get close to the end, there are a few items that have pretty low drop rates. Having to repeat the same fight fifteen times in a row, as a result, can get a drab. Luckily, it's not the exact same pattern of arrows every time, and the gameplay is engaging and fun enough that I didn't find this to be much of an issue, but it is something worth mentioning.If you're a fan of rhythm games, Sequence brings a twist on a traditional formula that makes it feel almost entirely new. I'm glad I put in all of the time that I did, and I think a lot of people would be surprised at how much they enjoy it.

Posted: June 5, 2012
												Puzzle Quest is to Bejeweled as Sequence is to DDR. Sequence is a dungeon crawler / RPG of sorts in which battles are done in DDR-like matches. Of course, arrows are hit with keys instead of a dancepad. The twist is that there are three different playing fields, and you have to switch between them. One regains mana as you hit notes, one blocks incoming damage when you hit the notes, and one is for casting spells. It's an interesting concept, and while it's done very well, it still seems to be amateurish. I'm glad I played it for a bit to get a good idea of the game, but it's not worth the grinding to continue.

Posted: March 18, 2012
												An extremely novel idea executed very well. The story is so-so, and the voice acting feels like it was done by bored devs, but the gameplay and audio really make this a win. It is a mixture of a rythm game and an RPG, which pits you against an oppenent to music where you must hit notes on your gamepad/keyboard in rythm on one of 3 boards to win. 1 board gains mana, 1 casts various spells, and 1 defends on attack. Balancing which spells you take into fights, which boards you focus on, and handling the special abilities that bosses throw at you is a lot of fun. It doesn't hurt that the musical selection is also very good.

Posted: October 3, 2016
												9/10An interesting blend of RPG and rhythm game that works incredibly well.Before the Echo is a game that combines the usual mechanics from rhythm games, where you have to press keys/buttons with the precise timing according to the music played, with elements from RPG games - leveling up, acquiring new gear, crafting, etc. And it does so very well. Basically, you have 3 screens - Attack, Defense and Mana. You use the Mana screen to recover Mana spent, the Attack screen to cast spells and the Defense screen to block incoming enemy attacks. To advance through the game, the player needs to know how to administer all three screens, changing between them whenever needed and using the proper timing to cast spells so that they're not cast at the same time an enemy attack is coming. The player can then learn new spells with varied effects like damage, damage over time, healing, creating a protective barrier, etc. The stronger the spell, the harder it is to cast it. Items improve the character's stats, making the character cause more damage, take less damage, recover more Mana, etc. Bosses have special abilities of their own that makes the battle harder.At first, the story seems to be overly simplistic, but as the game develops and the story unfolds, it's revealed that there's a lot more to it. Characters are interesting and there is character development throughout the story and the voice acting is very well done.For those who like a challenge, the game has four difficulty levels, with the hardest difficulty being for those lovers of rhythm games. The easiest difficulty still presents some challenge at later levels. (I actually had to reduce the difficulty to Easy for the last boss)And, of course, the soundtrack - truly amazing. I would have expected a good soundtrack for a game that is heavily based on music, but even then, it surpassed my expectations.Highly recommended.

												DDR/Frequency/Amplitude with an RPG twist. If you have ever been a fan of rhythm games, particularly those by Harmonix, you (hopefully) have come across the Frequency/Amplitude series. With its rapid track-switching gameplay, it was a unique and underappreciated entry in gaming history. Now, Sequence takes the track switching mechanic, applies simple DDR-style controls, and turns it into a monster-fighting RPG. It might sound crazy, but this is probably one of the best genre hybrids since Puzzle Fighter or Bust-a Move.

Posted: September 11, 2016
												Overall, I liked Before the Echo. I'm quite fond of rythm games in general (hard player on Guitar Hero, but not expert) and I liked the mix of rythm and RPG elements here.At first I wasn't much into the artstyle but I got used to it and kinda like it now. Same went for the dialogues which are a bit cheesy, especially in the beginning but then you get into the story and it's all ok. I found the story interesting and mostly went to the end of the game for that. Oh and the voiced credits is a nice little bonus ^^.As for the game mechanics, they mostly work well. You got stats to increase with stuff and level up, and spells to unlock and select for your build. The "line" selection during combats gives you control on how to spend your time and keystrokes.Though, the main negative point I have with this game lie in the game design. I started the game in Hard mode because I'm used to rythm games, it gives a little challenge and at first it was all ok. But, as after floor 3 you can't change difficulty, I regretted that choice much later when I needed to unlock more spells and couldn't because it was too hard for me (struggling with keys and controller, more used to frets). So I finished the game with only 7 of the 20+ (?) spells unlocked. And I unlocked 2 of them out of necessity for the floor 7 boss and final boss.The second complain I could make about the design of the game is about the final boss. On floor 7, once beat the boss of the level, you immediatly encounter the final boss and start the battle. There is a noticeable difficulty increase from the floor 7 boss. Therefore if you barely beat the previous boss, you can't beat the final boss and you have to go back and farm to level up and increase your stats. Also, because the damages notes are random, and in the battle the rythm of the song varies a lot, you end up in a total random fight when casting your spells and it ends up being infuriating. I lost my temper there with 20-30+ tries. I guess it's mostly because I didn't have the right spells unlocked but I was also struggling to unlock them.So, could be a bit better on some points, but overall a good and enjoyable game with a nice story to it. Liking rythm games is recommended to play this one ;)

Posted: April 1
												Before the Echo is a perfect mash-up of the rhythm and RPG genres. You use DDR style mechanics to cast powerful spells, restore your mana, and block incoming attacks as you make your way through the increasingly dangerous dungeons. The characters are really likeable, and I found myself enjoying the story way more than I expected. The villains in particular are quite entertaining, and while I won't spoil them here, you're likely to remember them long after you stop playing this game. The mechanics here are rock solid, and the difficulty curves quite nicely at each level. I mostly played on normal, since I sadly don't have the time to practice enough to master the hardest difficulties, but there's definitely enough value for both hardcore rhythm gamers and players new to the genre who want to see what it's all about. If you are new to rhythm games, be aware that grind is an essential part of the experience. You're going to be fighting the same monsters time and time again on each level to unlock the items you need, and the drop rates ensure that there's a random element that can halt your progression and add some frustration. In another game, this would be a huge negative, but rhythm games are based on the idea that you're going to play the same levels over and over again to master them. I never found the grind to be an issue, but I also beat Knights of Cydonia on Expert in GH3. My tolerance is pretty high for this kind of thing.If you love rhythm games already, buy this game. If you're not sure whether you like rhythm games but really like character focused RPGs, buy this game. If you hate rhythm games, I don't know how you got this far into my review, but this isn't going to be the game that changes your mind. I loved this game, and if you found this page in the first place, I'm willing to bet you will too.

Posted: July 6, 2016
												OUTSTANDING game.First of all, I adore indie games. I love the creativity and teamwork that comes with creating indie games, and they are my favorite genre to play and watch. I picked up this game on my queue during the Steam summer sale, but let me tell you, it's at least worth the five dollars standard price.As an avid lover of rhythm games, I was pleasantly surprised at the complexity of each level. The difficulty increased without overwhelming the player, and the spells come in a great variety that essentially allow the player to beat the game in their own style. The art style is consistent, entirely due to the fact that every visual was created by the same artist! And it's so very sweet on the eyes.Moving on to the characters, I have to say that while it is a rather short game (I finished all achievements in around 2-3 hours, after resetting my glitched game, a result of an error on my part) and thus we don't get to see much in terms of character depth or development, the characters' presence was enough to add quality and personality to the game without taking away the mystery and shock of the plot (I loved each of the Guardians and applaud the voice actors, as well as the artist, for providing such animated spirit). The ending leaves several questions unanswered, and if you're ambitious enough to get the hidden ending, you get a taste of even more secrets yet to be revealed.I couldn't put this game down. It was funny, intriguing, and the artwork and music are STELLAR!Now, to be fair, the game did have some drawbacks. I feel like the characters were a bit flat, but, if you play the game, you'll figure out why they seem to be so...scripted. It is a short game (hence the low price), but the crew that worked on it was so small! Aside from the voice actors, very few people put together a game that I will proudly call one of my all-time favorites. Iridium Studios, thank you for this masterpiece; I will cherish it for years to come.

												I can recommend this game to anyone who likes rhythm games. They did a good job at implementing RPG elements into the genre and wrapped everything up in a surprisingly decent story. Posted: February 17, 2016
												This game's Very Positive rating at the time of this review really boggles my mind. It's not that the game is bad, rather that its an idea who's implementation seems inherently flawed.The base mechanic of the game is the traditional "press one or more of the 4 directions on the beat as instructed". However, the twist is that you have three panels of arrows to rotate between and timing your presses correctly on them has different effects. There's your mana regen panel where each correct press earns you a little mana to cast spells. There's another that represents spellcasting where successfully landing a series of presses will cast a spell (more on this later). The last one represents defense where a sequence of arrows represents the enemy's attack; if you miss any here you take damage.The problem is that the defense panel's arrows (i.e. the enemy's attacks) occur at random, but you have to manually trigger your spellcast sequences. You may already see the issue here: you build mana, cast an attack spell, and arrows start to fall in the spell cast panel and defense panel simultaneously. The game's prescribed cure for this is to constantly keep up a "barrier" spell which effectively mutes the enemy. So the game requires you to continually recast this barrier spell so that you can actually cast the spells you want in between each barrier cast. In my opinion this is a kludge of a game mechanic. You get involved with a whole lot of busy work just to occasionally do something meaningful. Perhaps it all gets a bit smoother with some practice, but whats to engage you enough to want to get that good?I found a majority of the music to be ignorable at best. I've enjoyed some of Ronald Jenkees' music, but what's offered here I'd be reluctant to classify as even B-side music. The dialog is atrocious, the story is insignificant, and the graphics are the kind of crappy animatics that have now become standard fair in a sea of indie game dev mediocrity. The game would be perfectly suited for two hands on the keyboard, but I was forced into using a controller. (Oh I hope this wasn't just because I had a controller plugged into my PC; I'm not going back!)Perhaps worst yet is that the game devolves into a grind as each enemy you face has the chance to drop (at most?) one of three items of increasingly rarer chances to drop. You can face an enemy multiple times (enjoying the same music each time!) to get all items from an enemy. Why? Did the game need a time sink like this? Again, its more poor game design that not only contributes nothing fun, but actually contributes frustration.I really wanted to like this game. I had it on my wishlist as soon as it was released and bought it while it was still named Sequence. Despite the game's somewhat novel concept, it seems like the developer tried to throw a hodge-podge of ideas and twists at the rhythm genre, but just ended up with an overly-complicated and unfun mess.Unless you're some kind of rhythm game fanatic, skip this one. 6/10

Posted: April 1
												Before the Echo is a perfect mash-up of the rhythm and RPG genres. You use DDR style mechanics to cast powerful spells, restore your mana, and block incoming attacks as you make your way through the increasingly dangerous dungeons. The characters are really likeable, and I found myself enjoying the story way more than I expected. The villains in particular are quite entertaining, and while I won't spoil them here, you're likely to remember them long after you stop playing this game. The mechanics here are rock solid, and the difficulty curves quite nicely at each level. I mostly played on normal, since I sadly don't have the time to practice enough to master the hardest difficulties, but there's definitely enough value for both hardcore rhythm gamers and players new to the genre who want to see what it's all about. If you are new to rhythm games, be aware that grind is an essential part of the experience. You're going to be fighting the same monsters time and time again on each level to unlock the items you need, and the drop rates ensure that there's a random element that can halt your progression and add some frustration. In another game, this would be a huge negative, but rhythm games are based on the idea that you're going to play the same levels over and over again to master them. I never found the grind to be an issue, but I also beat Knights of Cydonia on Expert in GH3. My tolerance is pretty high for this kind of thing.If you love rhythm games already, buy this game. If you're not sure whether you like rhythm games but really like character focused RPGs, buy this game. If you hate rhythm games, I don't know how you got this far into my review, but this isn't going to be the game that changes your mind. I loved this game, and if you found this page in the first place, I'm willing to bet you will too.

Posted: September 11, 2016
												Overall, I liked Before the Echo. I'm quite fond of rythm games in general (hard player on Guitar Hero, but not expert) and I liked the mix of rythm and RPG elements here.At first I wasn't much into the artstyle but I got used to it and kinda like it now. Same went for the dialogues which are a bit cheesy, especially in the beginning but then you get into the story and it's all ok. I found the story interesting and mostly went to the end of the game for that. Oh and the voiced credits is a nice little bonus ^^.As for the game mechanics, they mostly work well. You got stats to increase with stuff and level up, and spells to unlock and select for your build. The "line" selection during combats gives you control on how to spend your time and keystrokes.Though, the main negative point I have with this game lie in the game design. I started the game in Hard mode because I'm used to rythm games, it gives a little challenge and at first it was all ok. But, as after floor 3 you can't change difficulty, I regretted that choice much later when I needed to unlock more spells and couldn't because it was too hard for me (struggling with keys and controller, more used to frets). So I finished the game with only 7 of the 20+ (?) spells unlocked. And I unlocked 2 of them out of necessity for the floor 7 boss and final boss.The second complain I could make about the design of the game is about the final boss. On floor 7, once beat the boss of the level, you immediatly encounter the final boss and start the battle. There is a noticeable difficulty increase from the floor 7 boss. Therefore if you barely beat the previous boss, you can't beat the final boss and you have to go back and farm to level up and increase your stats. Also, because the damages notes are random, and in the battle the rythm of the song varies a lot, you end up in a total random fight when casting your spells and it ends up being infuriating. I lost my temper there with 20-30+ tries. I guess it's mostly because I didn't have the right spells unlocked but I was also struggling to unlock them.So, could be a bit better on some points, but overall a good and enjoyable game with a nice story to it. Liking rythm games is recommended to play this one ;)

												A quirky and interesting DDR styled RPG. You attack, defend and regenerate MP through hitting notes during a song, and it gets pretty intense at times!The artwork is very pretty, the music is awesome and memorable, and the gameplay is fun as hell.The storyline is well crafted, with funny and interesting characters, and some very natural, yet entertaining dialogue. There's a very intriguing meta aspect to the game that only shows itself if you're interested in getting ALL of the achievements. However, I thought what the developer did was novel and impressive, and quite reminiscient of the Portal ARG, but on a smaller scale.Overall, this is one of the best Indie titles in my game library, and i've got a lot of respect and admiration for what Sequence is, and managed to do.

												A hidden gem in the rhythm game genre, Sequence combines DDR and RPG style battles to form a game completely addicting and worth coming back to. Posted: June 17, 2013
												This game has a charming storyline, referencing memes and elements of popular culture that should endear the average media-savvy player. However, it's main draw is its unique (as far as I know) music-based combat system.Find any youtube video of Sequence gameplay, TotalBiscuit for one. While you're watching, try to play along. Get in time with the beat and mime hitting the keys with your fingers. If you're liking the feel of it, buy this game. This feeling is enhanced once you have more agency in the game itself. if you've enjoyed any kind of rhythm game (Guitar Hero and etc.) and wanted to feel more like a badass while doing so, buy this game.Imagine what it must be like to jam along with electronic rock/techno, and then to pluck those tunes out of the air and convert them into raw magical power, which you then convert into a righteous fireball. For a small sum, you too can feel this power. I am a Music Magus; hear me groove.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												This game is basically DDR (on a controller/keyboard) mashed up with an RPG. If that sounds like heaven to you, then you're in for a good time. You battle monsters by completing sequences of notes, swapping between three different 'tracks' to attack, block, and charge up mana. The only major problem with this game is that it is *extremely* grind-y. To move past each level, you will need to craft a key, which requires collecting multiple items dropped from the monsters in that level. The monsters will only drop the items some of the time, and multiple items are usually required so you might end up fighting the same monster (and playing the same song) several times in a row. To make matters worse, crafting the items you need costs XP (meaning more battles to earn it back) and has a chance of failing (meaning even more battles to find all those items again). Playing the same song over and over again gets old very quickly.Overall, this is a good game for rhythm game fans, but be warned that it can get repetitive.

Posted: December 8, 2014
												When I heard about this indie title, being addicted to rhythm games like Stepmania and the possibility to play with a dancepad already got me interested. Ready to press arrows blindly according to the patterns, what I really found is that Sequence is a simple rpg game, in which are injected rhythmic mechanics with average difficulty. Mixed genres dude!Iridium Studios managed to produce something difficult to classify, yet the gameplay alone will entertain you for a decent amount of time. Yes, because while I enjoyed the game in its essence - the crafting system, the bosses and the good ol' leveling up - the story and the characters can't really get you hooked.Plus, I don't get why sentences by the main character are constantly being interrupted: you feel like a spoiled brat who needs a lesson for no particular reason, and the moment after we're oh so important like the future of the world depends on us. XDPlot twists, kinda forced, kinda rushed. Someone likes that, others don't.Despite the full controller support, I fully played it on keyboard - more fit in handling the controls in my opinion - and it was a good experience overall: my playtime reached ~20 hours, not bad for an indie game so I cannot say I didn't enjoy the run! The achievements offer a medium challenge to accomplish, so if you're an achievement hunter this is a nice game to 100% .Finally, would you look at the price! Looks like an on-sale game already, so definitely give this title a chance if you're searching for something outside the box.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												Bit of a mixed bag, Sequence is a rhythm game about using three different playing to fight monsters.  There's the defense field in which you defend against incoming attacks by aggressors by blocking their attacks pressing the corresponding keys.  The spell field in which you cast spells with different effects such as DoT, healing, or fast recharge low damage spells.  And the mana field in which you replenish mana, which is used to cast spells, you can only have one of these fields open at a time and there is a time limit for defeating the monster, which is an interesting concept.  The monsters have a chance of dropping various items, the lower the more rare and they all give a different amount of experience. You use your experience to craft items, spell scrolls, or keys which you use to use to progress, herein lies some of the problems of the game.  It feels like a grind, just a huge grind.  You end up wasting so much time either killing the same monster over and over again to find that ONE item you need to make better gear or spells, and you can end up wasting all of that precious expereince you earned making you down on experience, although you do lose out on some items.  It just gets very very repetitive around floor four you notice none of the spells bring anything new to the table.  It doesn't help the writing isn't super compelling.  Not to mention the music is reused and the only time you feel like you're actually playing a rhythm game is when you're in the mana field, which is when the keys actually feel like they correspond to the music.  It's got cute ideas but it's riddled with flaws, it's worth checking out if you feel confident sinking money into just to get a feel for it, hey if you're into the grind and slamming on keys for 10 seconds at a time (roughly how long it takes to get your mana replensihed) then be my guest.

Same went for the dialogues which are a bit cheesy, especially in the beginning but then you get into the story and it's all ok. You got stats to increase with stuff and level up, and spells to unlock and select for your build. The "line" selection during combats gives you control on how to spend your time and keystrokes.Though, the main negative point I have with this game lie in the game design. I started the game in Hard mode because I'm used to rythm games, it gives a little challenge and at first it was all ok. But, as after floor 3 you can't change difficulty, I regretted that choice much later when I needed to unlock more spells and couldn't because it was too hard for me (struggling with keys and controller, more used to frets). So I finished the game with only 7 of the 20+ (?) spells unlocked. And I unlocked 2 of them out of necessity for the floor 7 boss and final boss.The second complain I could make about the design of the game is about the final boss. On floor 7, once beat the boss of the level, you immediatly encounter the final boss and start the battle. There is a noticeable difficulty increase from the floor 7 boss. Therefore if you barely beat the previous boss, you can't beat the final boss and you have to go back and farm to level up and increase your stats. Also, because the damages notes are random, and in the battle the rythm of the song varies a lot, you end up in a total random fight when casting your spells and it ends up being infuriating. Posted: November 20, 2011
												Sequence is an excellent amalgamation of the RPG and rhythm genres. It features an engaging storyline, frenetic battles and plenty of humour. Your ascent up the tower is punctuated by meetings with Guardians - absurd characters who block your path - they're one of the many highlights of the game, along with the insanely catchy soundtrack. It is techno based and fits the mood of the game perfectly . Unfortunately, for the scope of the game, the soundtrack is a little too limited. There is a lot of grinding towards the end which exacerbates the problem, however, when you consider that the game was coded by one man, it is easy to forgive.To sum up, the game is a steal at $5.

Posted: November 24, 2012
												Sequence is a fun but simple DDR-style rhythm game with just enough uniqueness to keep the 10 hours it takes to reach 100% completion interesting. Its voice acted narrative, level-up system, and loot and inventory elements help it rise above its fundamentally repetitive nature. Several NPCs have some really great dialogue, which kept me eager to push through to the next story scene. It would have been nice to have a lot more variety in the music, but thankfully the handful of tracks, especially Ronald Jankee’s work, are all great. Considering only two people made the game (and it only cost me $1.25), Sequence was and is a memorable experience worth playing.

Posted: November 7, 2011
												Sequence does what Puzzle Quest did for block-clearing puzzlers but for the music/DDR-eque games.  The RPG elements and items collecting added to my music genre is a breath of fresh air and just what this genre needed.In this game you have not one, but 3 stream of arrows coming at you, one is health, another is mana and one is for spell activation. Posted: November 27, 2015
												SHORT VERSION | The game is pretty great.-----------------------------------------------------------------------LONG   VERSION | Pros:+ Characters are quirky, almost too much so, but I love each and every one of them.+ Game is challenging enough on preferred dificulty; with good balance between complexity and simplicity.+ The Humour is sometimes cringey, but for the most part its good for a giggle or two.+ The art style is consistent, it may not be for you but it does maintain aesthetic consistency.Cons:- Quite grindy at later stages.- Hearing the same song for the same enemy can get repetive very quickly when doing said grinding.- UI is console driven, and can be clunky at times for PC and keyboard.- Limited options if you're not ok with that sort of thing.The experience has been overall positive with this game, if you're not terribly into rythmn games or RPGs then one of the two genres might drag you through this game with some minor gripes, but for the most part even if you're not terribly into either it is worth it for the characters and the story.7/10

Posted: November 28, 2011
												If you love rhythm games, specifically DDR, then look no further. Taking rhythm to the next level, you are forced to pay attention to up to three separate flows of arrows at the same time..and all while keeping beat. Utilizing the Dance Dance Revolution style of rhythm game, these arrows shall be used for offense, defense, and recovery as you battle your way through foe after foe.What can make it particularly exciting is that no two battles are alike: by using your spells at different times, you essentially 'remix' the steps within the song yourself, providing a somewhat-new spin time and again.Of course, with a rhythm game, you want its soundtrack to shine, and Before the Echo does not disappoint. With a variety of techno-like beats providing you with sweet ear-candy, you'll find yourself swaying or bobbing to the beat as you work to defeat your foes.We've had Puzzle/Bejweled meets RPG in titles such as Puzzle Quest, and now the rhythm genre seeks to remix..and so far, it's shining.

Posted: December 4, 2015
The RPG where grinding is fun!If you are a fan of RPGs and rhythm games I highly recommend Before the Echo.I've completed the first of seven levels and my impressions so far are positive.  The first thing the player is treated to is the banter between the protaganist and his unseen guide.  The voice acting is good and the dialogue is consistently amusing with the occasional chuckle-worthy highlight.At each level the player is encouraged to create objects from recipes but the raw materials for each recipe are only acquired by defeating enemies.  The basic enemies drop one, two, or three different materials based on individual percentages so a specific drop is never guaranteed.  This requires the grind for which RPGs are famous.  The objects created from these recipes aren't required to progress in the game but because battles are resolved in fun rhythm challenges ala Dance Dance Revolution, why not obtain the materials to create the objects and try them out?I was pleasantly surprised that the first boss I encountered was an Internet meme and my interest is only piqued to see what subsequent levels will bring.You know you.  If resolving RPG combat by playing a rhythm game doesn't sound like fun to you, then take a pass on Before the Echo.  Otherwise, take a chance on it and you will likely be glad you did.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Had this game recommended to me as a good music game hybrid, and was pleasantly surprised.  I'm not usually an RPG fan, but this game is enjoyable so far and there's no question that I'll see it through to the end.As a long-time DDR/stepmania player, I stepped quite easily into hard mode.  The charts themselves are still pretty easy for me, and I can easily get 100% while unlocking spells.  However, during regular gameplay, coordinating switching between panes with hitting notes is a new and interesting challenge.The biggest downside so far is the lack of content.  The soundtrack, while well-made, is extremely limited, and you'll end up hearing the same handful of songs over and over (so far maybe a half dozen songs in the first 4/7 floors of the tower, compared to dozens/hundreds in your average true rhythm game).  That coupled with the fact that I'm better than halfway through the game in under 4 hours suggests that this game won't have replay value.Other thoughts:- The art is somewhat low-res (720p?) and you can't change resolutions.  You can choose full screen or windowed though.  Not something I notice during gameplay, but nowadays I'd expect full HD (or preferably vector) art.- So far I've only gotten one defensive spell and it's not that powerful.  There's a huge emphasis on attack-heavily-and-occasionally-heal with not much in the way of actually defending.  Some battles you can coast through without using the defense pane much at all, so it's not equally balanced throughout.- A lot of the items/spells seem ignorable in general, unless you're a compulsive completionist like I am.- Each floor of the tower has 3 different enemy battles (each with 3 different item drops), plus a boss battle.- It's interesting that the item drop probabilities are shown, that way you can quantify how bad your luck is when grinding.  Sure, I got the 35% item in 3 of my last 4 battles, but I only got one of the 85% item that I need three of.  Haha.- The boss battles don't seem to be replayable, but they do unlock new songs when you complete them that will be used in the higher levels of battle.- Most people complaining about the name change (from "Sequence") have no idea how trademark law works, or why companies are obligated to protect their trademarks.Overall, this game is well worth that 99c sale price, but it seems like something I'll play through once and then forget about.  I absolutely love the concept, but it needs more content for sure.

Posted: April 21, 2016
												Haven't finished yet, but I truly love the style, gameplay, concept, and mechanics of the game!Imagine an RPG style "guitar hero like" rhythm game. Got you hooked yet? Simply put, the player switches between 3 "fields" or screens (Defence, Spell, and Mana) while in game as arrows move down in each field. There's a great deal of multitasking involved because of casting spells, defending yourself, and gaining mana.You win by draining the opponent's HP to 0 by casting damaging spells, but you can lose by losing all of your health or by not winning by the end of the song. It's a great game that keeps you on your toes and equipping the right spells. That being said, don't feel as though there are "wrong" or "right" spells to use. Some are better for certain levels or battles, but I've been able to use the spells that fit my playstyle. Before the Echo is a great game for people who love RPGs but may not have all the time in the world to spend 60+ hours in.

Posted: September 11, 2016
												Overall, I liked Before the Echo. I'm quite fond of rythm games in general (hard player on Guitar Hero, but not expert) and I liked the mix of rythm and RPG elements here.At first I wasn't much into the artstyle but I got used to it and kinda like it now. Same went for the dialogues which are a bit cheesy, especially in the beginning but then you get into the story and it's all ok. I found the story interesting and mostly went to the end of the game for that. Oh and the voiced credits is a nice little bonus ^^.As for the game mechanics, they mostly work well. You got stats to increase with stuff and level up, and spells to unlock and select for your build. The "line" selection during combats gives you control on how to spend your time and keystrokes.Though, the main negative point I have with this game lie in the game design. I started the game in Hard mode because I'm used to rythm games, it gives a little challenge and at first it was all ok. But, as after floor 3 you can't change difficulty, I regretted that choice much later when I needed to unlock more spells and couldn't because it was too hard for me (struggling with keys and controller, more used to frets). So I finished the game with only 7 of the 20+ (?) spells unlocked. And I unlocked 2 of them out of necessity for the floor 7 boss and final boss.The second complain I could make about the design of the game is about the final boss. On floor 7, once beat the boss of the level, you immediatly encounter the final boss and start the battle. There is a noticeable difficulty increase from the floor 7 boss. Therefore if you barely beat the previous boss, you can't beat the final boss and you have to go back and farm to level up and increase your stats. Also, because the damages notes are random, and in the battle the rythm of the song varies a lot, you end up in a total random fight when casting your spells and it ends up being infuriating. I lost my temper there with 20-30+ tries. I guess it's mostly because I didn't have the right spells unlocked but I was also struggling to unlock them.So, could be a bit better on some points, but overall a good and enjoyable game with a nice story to it. Liking rythm games is recommended to play this one ;)

Posted: April 1
												Before the Echo is a perfect mash-up of the rhythm and RPG genres. You use DDR style mechanics to cast powerful spells, restore your mana, and block incoming attacks as you make your way through the increasingly dangerous dungeons. The characters are really likeable, and I found myself enjoying the story way more than I expected. The villains in particular are quite entertaining, and while I won't spoil them here, you're likely to remember them long after you stop playing this game. The mechanics here are rock solid, and the difficulty curves quite nicely at each level. I mostly played on normal, since I sadly don't have the time to practice enough to master the hardest difficulties, but there's definitely enough value for both hardcore rhythm gamers and players new to the genre who want to see what it's all about. If you are new to rhythm games, be aware that grind is an essential part of the experience. You're going to be fighting the same monsters time and time again on each level to unlock the items you need, and the drop rates ensure that there's a random element that can halt your progression and add some frustration. In another game, this would be a huge negative, but rhythm games are based on the idea that you're going to play the same levels over and over again to master them. I never found the grind to be an issue, but I also beat Knights of Cydonia on Expert in GH3. My tolerance is pretty high for this kind of thing.If you love rhythm games already, buy this game. If you're not sure whether you like rhythm games but really like character focused RPGs, buy this game. If you hate rhythm games, I don't know how you got this far into my review, but this isn't going to be the game that changes your mind. I loved this game, and if you found this page in the first place, I'm willing to bet you will too.

Posted: February 25, 2016
												I can recommend this game to anyone who likes rhythm games. They did a good job at implementing RPG elements into the genre and wrapped everything up in a surprisingly decent story. You can play this with a keyboard, but I found it a bit easier to play with a controller.So basically you "fight" yourself through a tower with seven floors and their guardians, and by fighting I mean you press directional arrows in three different windows to either defend yourself, regenerate mana or cast spells. If you're bad with coordination you might have trouble on the higher floors as switching quickly between the windows will become mandatory.My two major gripes with the game are a lack of different soundtracks early on (luckily there will be more variety later on, and some of the soundtracks are amazing) and incredibly frustrating RNG at times. Both item drops and crafting items are based on a percentage, the latter costing experience which makes failing a little more frustrating. If you want to get everything, you WILL have to grind a bit. Other than that, I found it overall enjoyable and enticing.

Posted: February 17, 2016
												This game's Very Positive rating at the time of this review really boggles my mind. It's not that the game is bad, rather that its an idea who's implementation seems inherently flawed.The base mechanic of the game is the traditional "press one or more of the 4 directions on the beat as instructed". However, the twist is that you have three panels of arrows to rotate between and timing your presses correctly on them has different effects. There's your mana regen panel where each correct press earns you a little mana to cast spells. There's another that represents spellcasting where successfully landing a series of presses will cast a spell (more on this later). The last one represents defense where a sequence of arrows represents the enemy's attack; if you miss any here you take damage.The problem is that the defense panel's arrows (i.e. the enemy's attacks) occur at random, but you have to manually trigger your spellcast sequences. You may already see the issue here: you build mana, cast an attack spell, and arrows start to fall in the spell cast panel and defense panel simultaneously. The game's prescribed cure for this is to constantly keep up a "barrier" spell which effectively mutes the enemy. So the game requires you to continually recast this barrier spell so that you can actually cast the spells you want in between each barrier cast. In my opinion this is a kludge of a game mechanic. You get involved with a whole lot of busy work just to occasionally do something meaningful. Perhaps it all gets a bit smoother with some practice, but whats to engage you enough to want to get that good?I found a majority of the music to be ignorable at best. I've enjoyed some of Ronald Jenkees' music, but what's offered here I'd be reluctant to classify as even B-side music. The dialog is atrocious, the story is insignificant, and the graphics are the kind of crappy animatics that have now become standard fair in a sea of indie game dev mediocrity. The game would be perfectly suited for two hands on the keyboard, but I was forced into using a controller. (Oh I hope this wasn't just because I had a controller plugged into my PC; I'm not going back!)Perhaps worst yet is that the game devolves into a grind as each enemy you face has the chance to drop (at most?) one of three items of increasingly rarer chances to drop. You can face an enemy multiple times (enjoying the same music each time!) to get all items from an enemy. Why? Did the game need a time sink like this? Again, its more poor game design that not only contributes nothing fun, but actually contributes frustration.I really wanted to like this game. I had it on my wishlist as soon as it was released and bought it while it was still named Sequence. Despite the game's somewhat novel concept, it seems like the developer tried to throw a hodge-podge of ideas and twists at the rhythm genre, but just ended up with an overly-complicated and unfun mess.Unless you're some kind of rhythm game fanatic, skip this one. 6/10

Posted: October 3, 2016
												9/10An interesting blend of RPG and rhythm game that works incredibly well.Before the Echo is a game that combines the usual mechanics from rhythm games, where you have to press keys/buttons with the precise timing according to the music played, with elements from RPG games - leveling up, acquiring new gear, crafting, etc. And it does so very well. Basically, you have 3 screens - Attack, Defense and Mana. You use the Mana screen to recover Mana spent, the Attack screen to cast spells and the Defense screen to block incoming enemy attacks. To advance through the game, the player needs to know how to administer all three screens, changing between them whenever needed and using the proper timing to cast spells so that they're not cast at the same time an enemy attack is coming. The player can then learn new spells with varied effects like damage, damage over time, healing, creating a protective barrier, etc. The stronger the spell, the harder it is to cast it. Items improve the character's stats, making the character cause more damage, take less damage, recover more Mana, etc. Bosses have special abilities of their own that makes the battle harder.At first, the story seems to be overly simplistic, but as the game develops and the story unfolds, it's revealed that there's a lot more to it. Characters are interesting and there is character development throughout the story and the voice acting is very well done.For those who like a challenge, the game has four difficulty levels, with the hardest difficulty being for those lovers of rhythm games. The easiest difficulty still presents some challenge at later levels. (I actually had to reduce the difficulty to Easy for the last boss)And, of course, the soundtrack - truly amazing. I would have expected a good soundtrack for a game that is heavily based on music, but even then, it surpassed my expectations.Highly recommended.

Posted: April 1
												Before the Echo is a perfect mash-up of the rhythm and RPG genres. You use DDR style mechanics to cast powerful spells, restore your mana, and block incoming attacks as you make your way through the increasingly dangerous dungeons. The characters are really likeable, and I found myself enjoying the story way more than I expected. The villains in particular are quite entertaining, and while I won't spoil them here, you're likely to remember them long after you stop playing this game. The mechanics here are rock solid, and the difficulty curves quite nicely at each level. I mostly played on normal, since I sadly don't have the time to practice enough to master the hardest difficulties, but there's definitely enough value for both hardcore rhythm gamers and players new to the genre who want to see what it's all about. If you are new to rhythm games, be aware that grind is an essential part of the experience. You're going to be fighting the same monsters time and time again on each level to unlock the items you need, and the drop rates ensure that there's a random element that can halt your progression and add some frustration. In another game, this would be a huge negative, but rhythm games are based on the idea that you're going to play the same levels over and over again to master them. I never found the grind to be an issue, but I also beat Knights of Cydonia on Expert in GH3. My tolerance is pretty high for this kind of thing.If you love rhythm games already, buy this game. If you're not sure whether you like rhythm games but really like character focused RPGs, buy this game. If you hate rhythm games, I don't know how you got this far into my review, but this isn't going to be the game that changes your mind. I loved this game, and if you found this page in the first place, I'm willing to bet you will too.

Posted: April 21, 2016
												Haven't finished yet, but I truly love the style, gameplay, concept, and mechanics of the game!Imagine an RPG style "guitar hero like" rhythm game. Got you hooked yet? Simply put, the player switches between 3 "fields" or screens (Defence, Spell, and Mana) while in game as arrows move down in each field. There's a great deal of multitasking involved because of casting spells, defending yourself, and gaining mana.You win by draining the opponent's HP to 0 by casting damaging spells, but you can lose by losing all of your health or by not winning by the end of the song. It's a great game that keeps you on your toes and equipping the right spells. That being said, don't feel as though there are "wrong" or "right" spells to use. Some are better for certain levels or battles, but I've been able to use the spells that fit my playstyle. Before the Echo is a great game for people who love RPGs but may not have all the time in the world to spend 60+ hours in.

												I went into this game fully knowing it was a DDR game. Being mediocre at it, i thought that it would be a simple 2 maybe 3 hours to finish this.Now, what i did not expect was the engaging storyline, the funny banter and the relationships that develop. If you are a storyline kind of person and can do so-so in stepmania, i would encourage you to give this a go. While "grinding" for levels is a thing in this game, you'll notice that you would do the same in any DDR / stepmania type of game. Watch yourself get better as you aim for that perfect all the while gaining more power (by leveling) and actual skill of both memory and reflexes.All in all, i find this to be my hidden gem. Simple gameplay, GREAT storyline and above all memorable chracters.

Posted: January 10, 2016
												The game's a grindfest if you try to get all of the achievements, and not really deserving of the "10+ hours worth of gameplay" description, but overall decent writing (ending was a bit suspect; a lot of the boss dialogue was pretty good) and fun gameplay; the gimmick was fun for a few hours until it alternated between getting boring due to overlevelling while grinding for items and 2HKOing everything (and not immediately since spells take time to wind up), and being reasonably fun again afterwards. (Floor 7 gimmick was annoying as heck though)I recently got access to my DDR pad again (I had a better (actually metal) one but the USB connector doesn't seem to work), so I tried playing the game with that (This is possible if you use AntiMicro): there weren't enough buttons and trying to press the A and B buttons to switch panes was disorienting at best since muscle memory from DDR had me keep my other foot on the center panel instead of doing anything productive, so I ended up getting a keyboard, remapping F1 to F6 as the spell keys and F9 and F10 as the pane switch keys, holding it like a guitar, and mashing the F# buttons appropriately.This worked surprisingly well overall, except my DDR pad is garbage at detecting inputs, which was frustrating. It also didn't help that my balance was skewed by holding the keyboard (Playing on the Hard difficulty, for reference, so there are a nontrivial number of notes) and the fact that I looked like a dork while jumping around with it, but still, it was reasonably fun (and good exercise too, especially since you only have your arm up to your elbow for balance).Definitely worth $1 when on sale, and definitely worth buying my first $20 steam gift card. Would recommend.

Posted: April 20
												Before the Echo is basically what happens when you mash a ddr game with a rpg.It's a standard rpg experience. There are varying levels of grindiness depending on how completionist/what difficulty you're playing at. There is also a fair amount of repetitiveness.But, your weapon of choice is music. Or more specifically, how good you are at rhythm games and multitasking. You will be hearing the same songs multiple times so if you don't like the songs, you're out of luck.The story plays out like a standard visual novel so if you really don't like cheesy lines and a generic storyline, maybe take that into account.All in all, as someone who likes rpg and heavily enjoys music games, I highly recommend this game to people of a similar likeness. It's a decent length, has just the right amount of grind, quite smooth gameplay, a decent soundtrack, all wrapped up with a smidgen of comedy.

Posted: April 23
												Formerly known as Sequence, Before the Echo is a rhythm-based RPG. It features some of the music of a wonderful artist named Ronald Jenkees (check him out on the Youtubes) among others. The game genre puts a relatively innovative spin on the rhythm games of the time. Working both to progress through levels as well as manage your resources, this game is a clever mash up. The dialogue and plot of this game, while cheesy at times, is pretty hilarious and I thoroughly enjoyed watching every single cutscene. The suspense of what the situation is regarding the main characters is profoundly strong for a seemly small game. One of the few games so far that I have ever 100% in achievements.
